revision.text:
The '''1990 October Revolution Parade''' was the last parade commemorating the 1917 [[October Revolution]] during the [[Soviet Union]]'s existence. It celebrated the 73rd anniversary of the revolution. It was the first and last parade attended by [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] in his position as [[President of the Soviet Union]]. At the chimes of the [[Kremlin Clock]], Gorbachev gave an address to the nation. It would be the first and last time a Soviet leader made an address on [[Lenin's Mausoleum]] during an October Revolution parade. After the anthem was played, the commander of the parade Colonel General [[Nikolai Kalinin]] reported to the parade inspector [[Marshal of the Soviet Union]] [[Dmitry Yazov]]. Providing the music for the parade was the head of the central orchestra of the [[Moscow Military District]], Major General Nikolai Mikhailov.{{Citation|last=RedSamurai84|title=HD Final Soviet October Revolution Parade, 1990 Парад 7 Ноября|date=2016-05-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PxZux1KLhAQ&list=PL0g-YW_Z9IPCaYXm13-jBZ8ohjSHgCO5_&index=31|accessdate=2016-10-23}} == Full order of the marchpast == {{unreferenced section|date=February 2017}} At the front of the parade was the limousine carrying the commander of the parade Colonel General Nikolai Kalinin. '''Massed Bands''' * Corps of Drums of the Moscow Military College * Massed Military Bands of the Moscow Military District '''Ground Column''' * M. V. Frunze Military Academy * V. I. Lenin Political Academy * Feliz Dzerzhinsky Artillery Academy * Military Engineering Academy * Military Armored Forces Academy Marshal Rodion Malinovskovy * Military Academy of Chemical Defense and Control * Yuri Gagarin Air Force Academy * [[Zhukovsky Air Force Engineering Academy|Prof. Nikolai Zhukovsky Air Force Engineering Academy]] * Naval Engineering School * [[98th Guards Airborne Division]] * Moscow Border Guards Institute of the Border Defence Forces of the KGB "Moscow City Council" * 336th Marine Brigade * [[ODON|OMSDON]] regiment * [[Suvorov Military School|Suvorov Military Academy]] * [[Nakhimov Naval School]] * Moscow Military High Command Training School "Supreme Soviet of the Russian SFSR" '''Mobile Column''' * 2nd Guards Tamanskaya Motorized Rifle Division ** [[BTR-80]] ** [[BMP-2]] * 98th Guards Airborne Division ** [[BMD-2]] * 4th Guards Kantermirovsky Tank Division ** [[T-80]] * Rocket Forces and Artillery ** [[2S3 Akatsiya]] ** [[2S19 Msta]] ** [[BM-21 Grad]] == Parades in cities in the USSR == Revolution Day parades and celebrations were also held in the following USSR republics and cities: * {{Flagicon|Ukrainian SSR}}[[Kiev]], [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukrainian SSR]], [[Victory Square, Kiev|Victory Square]]{{Cite web|url=http://ukrweekly.com/archive/1990/The_Ukrainian_Weekly_1990-45.pdf|title=Alternative Meetings in Kiev Observe the October Revolution|last=|first=|date=|website=The Ukrainian Weekly|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} * {{Flagicon|Lithuanian SSR|1988}}[[Vilnius]], [[Lithuanian SSR]], [[Gediminas Avenue]]{{Cite web|url=http://ukrweekly.com/archive/1990/The_Ukrainian_Weekly_1990-45.pdf|title=Revolution Day Parade turns violent in Vilnius|last=|first=|date=|website=The Ukrainian Weekly|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The parade location in Kiev was changed from [[Khreshchatyk]] Street to Victory Square by order of the Kiev City Council. == Attempted assassination of Gorbachev == At 11:00 AM, an hour after the parade began, an attempt to kill President Gorbachev was made by Alexander Shmonov.{{Cite news|url=http://rbth.com/politics_and_society/politics/2017/02/16/the-last-soviet-terrorist-the-man-who-tried-to-assassinate-gorbachev_703611|title=The last Soviet terrorist: The man who tried to assassinate Gorbachev|last=Levkovich|first=Yevgeny|date=2017-02-16|work=Russia Beyond The Headlines|access-date=2017-03-30|language=en-US}} The two bullets he fired missed and he was tackled to the ground by crowds of demonstrators. Shmonov was the last would-be-assassin of the Soviet period before the USSR's dissolution in 1991. He was sent to forced treatment which took a heavy toll on his mental state. Three weeks prior to the parade, Shmonov bought a double-barreled hunting rifle. He took out his rifle and was spotted immediately by the police, and as he was taking aim, an officer ran over and jerked the rifle by the barrel as the crowd jumped on him. Soviet Central television did not broadcast the assassination attempt and resumed its regular broadcasting at 11:25 AM.{{refn|group=nb|"Broadcast television was interrupted at 11:10 a concert of classical music and resumed at 11:25."{{Cite web|url=https://ru.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=%D0%A8%D0%BC%D0%BE%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B2,_%D0%90%D0%BB%D0%B5%D0%BA%D1%81%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B4%D1%80_%D0%90%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%82%D0%BE%D0%BB%D1%8C%D0%B5%D0%B2%D0%B8%D1%87&oldid=87373265|title=Шмонов, Александр Анатольевич|date=2017-09-01|website=Wikipedia|access-date=2017-09-06}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=March 2017}}}} {{Infobox criminal | name = Alexander Shmonov
Александр Шмонов | image = | birth_name = Aleksandr Anatolevich Shmonov | occupation = Locksmith | birth_date = {{Birth date|1952|2|21}} | birth_place = [[Leningrad]], [[RSFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | nationality = [[Soviet]] | date = November 7, 1990 | time = {{Circa|11:00 a.m.}} | targets = Mikhail Gorbachev, Soviet Leadership | locations = Moscow, Soviet Union | fatalities = 0 | injuries = 0 | motive = }} ==Notes== {{reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{YouTube|PxZux1KLhAQ|Full parade footage}} *{{YouTube|FqS_iBNiCvo|Raw parade footage|link=no}} {{Annual Great October Socialist Revolution Parade}} [[Category:1990 in Russia|October Revolution Parade]] [[Category:October Revolution parades]] [[Category:November 1990 events]] [[Category:1990s in Moscow]] [[Category:Last events]] [[Category:1990 in the Soviet Union]]

revision.text:
<!-- [[File:ARKhan.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Vice-Admiral [[Syed Mohammad Ahsan|S.M. Ahsan]] of Pakistan Navy.]] --> '''Ahsan's Formula''' (or an '''Admiral Ahsan Mission''') was a fact-finding expedition and peace initiative mission dispatched by the [[Government of Pakistan|Pakistani government]] to [[East Pakistan]] in early 1971.{{rp|103-102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> The mission was led by [[Vice-Admiral]] [[Syed Mohammad Ahsan]], then-Governor of [[East Pakistan]] and commander of the [[Pakistan Eastern Command|East-Pakistani military]], with the support from his [[chief of staff]] [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan|Yaqub Ali Khan]] to investigate the prelude causes of the [[Bangladesh Liberation War|civil war progress]] and to workout a peace initiative to end the political crises in the [[East Pakistan]] to avoid international humiliation of Pakistan.{{rp|109–110}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham">{{cite book|last1=Ehtisham|first1=S. Akhtar|title=A Medical Doctor Examines Life on Three Continents: A Pakistani View|date=1998|publisher=Algora Publishing|isbn=9780875866345|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IuseZxgbn8oC&pg=PA109&dq=admiral+ahsan+formula&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiYl5mx5-XQAhVCrVQKHWcgDfQQuwUIHTAA#v=onepage&q=admiral%20ahsan%20formula&f=false|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref>
The mission came in the wake of increasingly strained and difficult foreign relations between Pakistan and [[East Pakistan]] since the civil unrest had gripped East Pakistan as Awami League's demonstrations and demands for the provincial autonomy against Pakistan's central administration after the [[Pakistani general elections, 1970|general elections]] held in 1970.{{rp|156}}<ref name="Lancer Publishers, Rao">{{cite book|last1=Rao|first1=K. V. Krishna|title=Prepare Or Perish: A Study of National Security|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9788172120016}}</ref> Following the [[1971 Dhaka University massacre|violent raids]] in [[Dhaka University]] by the [[Bangladesh Police|East-Pakistani police]] supported by the military stationed in East, and ultimatum issued by India to intervene in the conflict, the Pakistan had authorized Admiral Ahsan to carry out the investigations into a possible Indian intervention through a cable communication to work out a possible peace solution to end violence in East.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /><ref name="Progressive Publishers">{{cite book|last1=Rizvi|first1=Hasan Askari|title=Internal Strife and External Intervention: India's Role in the Civil War in East Pakistan (Bangladesh)|publisher=Progressive Publishers}}</ref>
The recommendations based on the studies were roughly based on [[Six point movement|six-point movement]] proposed by the [[Awami League]] in 1969 and called for: ** [[Islamabad|Center]] [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission Report|would control]] the [[Ministry of Defence (Pakistan)|defence]], [[Military of Pakistan|military]], [[Foreign policy of Pakistan|foreign]], [[National Security Council of Pakistan|national security]], and the [[Pakistan Rupee|currency]].{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> ** [[Eighteenth Amendment to the Constitution of Pakistan|Province(s) would have the authority to raise revenue]] and would fund the subject of the federation.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> ** [[Repatriation]] of [[West Pakistanis|Western Pakistanis]] citizens and bureaucrats to Pakistan with [[East Pakistanis|Eastern Pakistanis]] stationed back to East. ** Equal divisions of national assets between Pakistan and East Pakistan based on population census.
The Mission also called for Pakistan becoming a [[Federation of Pakistan|co-federation]] with Yahya Khan as President with Mujib being the Prime Minister of East while Bhutto being Prime Minister of Pakistan.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> Civil servants from Pakistan stationed in East would repatriated to Pakistan and the national assets would equally be divided between East and West Pakistan.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> The proposal was met with strong support from the [[United Nations|international community]] and India fell in line though reluctant.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" />
The mission was met with support from the [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Yahya Khan]], opposition leaders [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto]] and [[Sheikh Mujibur Rahman]] and the [[United Nations|international community]] while India fell in line despite criticising Pakistan.{{rp|102}}<ref name="Algora Publishing, Ehtisham" /> However, the Mission was not supported by the military elements in the [[President Yahya Khan#President of Pakistan|Yahya administration]] who debated acrimoniously over the scope of the mission's recommendations among the advisors in Yahya administration.{{rp|206–207}}<ref name="University Press, Ahmad">{{cite book|last1=Ahmed|first1=Moudud|title=Bangladesh: constitutional quest for autonomy, 1950-1971|date=1979|publisher=University Press|isbn=3515029087}}</ref> Eventually, the mission studies and recommendations at the [[National Security Council (Pakistan)|National Security Council]] cabinet meeting were vetoed and no further study missions were directed to the East Pakistan.{{rp|122–137}}<ref name="Stacey International">{{cite book|last1=Bush|first1=Muhammad Yusuf|first2=Hamid|last2=Jalal|title=Pakistan: Past & Present; a comprehensive study|date=1977|publisher=Stacey International|location=London|pages=288|isbn=0950330493}}</ref>
By the fall of 1971, the mission's recommendations were bypassed with Admiral Ahsan submitting his resignation and posted back to Pakistan, followed by the resignation of [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Sahabzada Yaqub Khan|Yaqub Ali Khan]].
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==Bibliography== {{small| * {{cite book | last =Salik, PA | first =Brigadier Siddiq | author-link =Siddique Salik | date =1997 | orig-year =First published in 1977 | title =Witness To Surrender | publisher =Oxford University Press | chapter =§The Man of Honor and Integrity: Admiral Syed Mohammad Ahsan, Unified Commander of Pakistan Armed Forces in East Pakistan | pages =60–90 | isbn =978-0-19-577761-1}} }} * {{small|{{cite book|last1=Ahmed|first1=Masud|title=Dusk, Dawn and Liberation|publisher=Author House|isbn=9781491881033}} }} * {{small|{{cite book|last1=Shariff|first1=Admiral Mohammad|title=Admiral's Diary: Battling Through Stormy Sea Life for Decades|date=2010|publisher=Army Press|pages=415|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UbS5YgEACAAJ&dq=admiral's+diary&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjNx8-PmebQAhVhzFQKHaZvCYwQ6AEIHDAA}} }}

revision.text:
The '''Asian Science Camp (ASC)''' is an annual forum for pre-[[college|collegiate]] and college students which aims at promoting discussion and cooperation among [[Asia]]n students for the betterment of science in the Asian region. The first ASC was held at [[Taipei]] in 2007, and was subsequently held at [[Bali]] (2008), [[Tsukuba|Tsukuba (Japan)]] (2009), [[Mumbai]] (2010), [[Daejeon|Daejeon (South Korea)]] (2011), Hebrew University of Jerusalem ([[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]]) (2012). This idea of an annual camp was co-proposed by [[Yuan Tseh Lee]] and [[Masatoshi Koshiba]] at the 2005 [[Nobel Laureate Meetings at Lindau]]. The ASC is modeled after the Lindau meetings.<ref name='hbcse'>{{cite web| url = http://asc2010.hbcse.tifr.res.in/ | title = Asian Science Camp 2010, Mumbai, India | accessdate = 2011-08-11 | publisher = [[TIFR]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110721181127/http://asc2010.hbcse.tifr.res.in/| archivedate= 21 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name='asc2011about'>{{cite web|url=http://www.asc2011.kr/about.html |title=ASC 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812084536/http://www.asc2011.kr/about.html |archivedate=2011-08-12 |df= }}</ref><ref name='asc2012'>{{cite web | url = http://www.asc2012.ort.org.il | title = Asian Science Camp 2012, Jerusalem, Israel | accessdate = 2012-07-27}}</ref>
==Background== The idea of the Asian Science Camp<ref>[http://www.asiansciencecamp.org/ Asian Science Camp]</ref> was co-proposed in September 2005 after the 55th Annual meeting of Nobel Laureates and Students in Lindau, Germany, by Professor [[Yuan Tseh Lee]] (1986 Nobel Laureate in Chemistry) from Chinese Taipei, and Professor [[Masatoshi Koshiba]] (2002 Nobel Laureate in Physics) from [[Japan]]. The proposal expressed the aim to enlighten science talented youths through discussions and dialogues with top scholars in the world, and promoting international friendship and cooperation among best young students of the next generation in Asia. The Lindau Meetings will serve as a model. The Asian Science Camp would invite a dozen Nobel Laureates or world-distinguished scientists as speakers and devise an interesting program to attract all the participants, including plenary sessions, round table discussions, student master dialogues, a creative poster competition, social events and excursion. The working language would be English. This proposal was soon discussed in a board meeting of the Wu Chien-Shiung Education Foundation and was approved unanimously by the board.
The governing body of the Asian Science Camp is the International Board of Asian Science Camp (IBASC). IBASC is a not- for- profit organization, consisting of non-governmental educational institutions. The 2007 Asian Science Camp was organized by the [[Wu Chien-Shiung Education Foundation]] with the assistance of [[Academia Sinica in Taiwan]]. This non-government Foundation was established in 1995 to commemorate the monumental contributions of Madame Dr. Wu Chien-Shiung to physics and her lifelong love for science education. Since its inauguration in Taiwan in August 2007, the Asian Science Camp has become an International annual event in Asia.<ref>[http://asc2008.suryainstitute.org Asian Science Camp 2008, Bali, Indonesia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110227011855/http://asc2008.suryainstitute.org/ |date=February 27, 2011 }}</ref>
==Host Countries== ''2018'' - {{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Manado]], [[Indonesia]]
''2017'' - {{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Kampar, Perak|Kampar]], [[Malaysia]]
''2016'' - {{flagicon|India}} [[Bengaluru]], [[India]]
''2015'' - {{flagicon|Thailand}} [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]
''2014'' - {{flagicon|Singapore}} [[Singapore]]
2013 - {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Tsukuba, Ibaraki|Tsukuba]], [[Japan]]
2012 - {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]]<ref>[http://www.asc2012.ort.org.il/ 2012 ASC, Jerusalem Israel]</ref>
2011 - {{flagicon|South Korea}} [[Daejeon]], [[South Korea]]
2010 - {{flagicon|Japan}} [[Tsukuba, Ibaraki|Tsukuba]], [[Japan]]
2009 - {{flagicon|India}} [[Mumbai]], [[India]]
2008 - {{flagicon|Indonesia}} [[Bali]], [[Indonesia]]
2007 - {{flagicon|Taiwan}} [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]]
== First Asian Science Camp ==
The First Asian Science Camp was held at [[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] 5 August to 11 August 2007.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wcscamp-register.com/asiansciencecamp_web/2007/english/eng_program.htm|title=2007 Asian Science Camp|website=www.wcscamp-register.com|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> It organized by [http://www.wcs.org.tw/ Wu Chien Shiung Foundation] with assistance by Academia Sinica in Taiwan. Around 400 students<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wcscamp-register.com/asiansciencecamp_web/2007/english/eng_participants.htm|title=2007 Asian Science Camp|website=www.wcscamp-register.com|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> and five Noble Laureates<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wcscamp-register.com/asiansciencecamp_web/2007/english/eng_lecturers.htm|title=2007 Asian Science Camp|website=www.wcscamp-register.com|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> attended this event.
The program of the First Asian Science Camp was supported and funded by Ministry of Education, National Science Council, Academia Sinica, National Women's League of the R.O.C., Macronix International Co., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacture Company Ltd., Hewlett-Packard Company (Taiwan), MediaTek Inc., Powerchip Semiconductor Corp., Li Ching Cultural and Education Foundation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wcscamp-register.com/asiansciencecamp_web/2007/english/eng_intro.htm|title=2007 Asian Science Camp|website=www.wcscamp-register.com|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
==Sixth Asian Science Camp== {{main|Sixth Asian Science Camp}} The [[Sixth Asian Science Camp]] hosted by [[Israel]] took place in the Hebrew University Safra Campus [[Jerusalem]] in 2012 was, by then, the largest event in terms of the number of students from when the project first began. Approximately 300 students, 5 Nobel Prize recipients, and 20 leading experts attended the event.
== Tenth Asian Science Camp == {{main|Asian Science Camp 2016}}
Asian Science Camp 2016, was organised by jointly by [[Department of Science and Technology (India)|Department of Science and Technology, Government of India]] and [[Indian Institute of Science]] from 21 August to 27 August 2016. The venue for the program was J N Tata Auditorium, Indian Institute od Science, Bangalore, India.
=== Speakers === The main speakers in Tenth Asian Science Camp, 2016 were: * [[C. N. R. Rao|Dr. C. N. R. Rao]] * [[Georg Bednorz|Dr. J. Georg Bednorz]] * [[Raghavendra Gadagkar|Prof. Raghvendra Gadagkar]] * [[Cédric Villani|Dr. Cedric Villani]] * [[Takaaki Kajita|Dr Takaaki Kajita]] * [[Ajay K. Sood|Dr Ajay K Sood]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc2016.org.in/program-speakers.php|title=Asian Science Camp 2016|website=www.asc2016.org.in|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
=== Program Overview === The following activities were planned during the Asian Science Camp 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc2016.org.in/program-overview.php|title=Asian Science Camp 2016|website=www.asc2016.org.in|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
==== Academic Program ==== * Plenary lectures by Distinguished [[Scientist]]s (Distinguished Awardees from Asia and Nobel Laureates) * Individual lectures pertaining to different disciplines * Laboratory demonstrations * Panel discussions * Theme Presentations by students * Poster presentation by students
==== Sightseeing and excursions ==== * Visit of historical places in [[Bangalore]] and in [[Mysore]] * Visit of science and technology museum * Cultural program
=== Participation === Participation in the ASC 2016 was through invitation only. The Organizing Committee sent an invitation to the contact person of each country/region to announce the ASC 2016 to high schools and universities, so as to initiate the local process to select student delegates. The last date for receiving the nominations was 30 April 2016.
There was no registration fee, and the Organizing Committee provided the living and local expenses of participants associated with ASC 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc2016.org.in/participation.php|title=Asian Science Camp 2016|website=www.asc2016.org.in|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
Around 240 students, including 200 from abroad and 40 from [[India]] participated in the camp. in addition there were 40 overseas mentor and 30 organizing committee members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc2016.org.in/program-overview.php|title=Asian Science Camp 2016|website=www.asc2016.org.in|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
=== Accommodation === Accommodation for the speakers was arranged at The Taj Vivanta, [[Yeswanthpur]], [[Bangalore]].
Accommodation for other participants was arranged at 37th Crescent Hotel, Bengaluru, Hotel Bangalore International, Crescent Road, Bengaluru and Goldfinch Hotel, Bengaluru.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.asc2016.org.in/info-accommodation.php|title=Asian Science Camp 2016|website=www.asc2016.org.in|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Recurring events established in 2007]] [[Category:Science events]]

/* See also */
revision.text:
{{About|the use of this phrase in computing|other uses|Birds of a Feather (disambiguation)}} In [[computing]], '''BoF (birds of a feather)''' can refer to: * An informal discussion group. Unlike [[special interest group]]s or [[working group]]s, BoFs are informal and often formed in an ''ad hoc'' manner. The acronym is used by the [[Internet Engineering Task Force]] (IETF) to denote initial meetings of members interested in a particular issue. * A BoF session, an informal meeting at [[Business conference|conference]]s, where the attendees group together based on a shared interest and carry out discussions without any pre-planned agenda.
==Details== The first use of this term among computer specialists is uncertain, but it was employed during [[DECUS]] conferences and may have been used at [[SHARE (computing)|SHARE]] [[user group]] meetings in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite book | first=Mad | last=Macz | year=2002 | title=Internet Underground: The Way of the Hacker | publisher=PageFree Publishing, Inc | isbn=1930252536 }}</ref>
BoFs can facilitate networking and partnership formation among subgroups, including functionally oriented groups such as CEOs or geographically oriented groups.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2001_March_13/ai_71627961 | title="Birds of a Feather" Sessions Highlight Revamped ISPCON Spring Conference | date=March 13, 2001 | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | accessdate=2008-05-31}}</ref> BoFs generally allow for more audience interaction than the panel discussions typically seen at conventions; the discussions are not completely unguided, though, as there is still a discussion leader.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2004_May_18/ai_n6032036 | title=Mac Users to Drive Discussions During Birds of a Feather Meetings at Macworld Conference & Expo | date=May 18, 2004 | publisher=[[Business Wire]] | accessdate=2008-05-31}}</ref>
===Term=== The term is derived from the proverb "[[wikt:birds of a feather flock together|Birds of a feather flock together]]". The ([[idiomatic]]) phrase ''"birds of a feather"'' meaning "people having similar characters, backgrounds, interests, or beliefs". In old poetic English, "birds of a feather" means birds which have the same kind of feathers, so the proverb refers to the fact that birds congregate with birds of their own species.
== See also == * [[Unconference]] * [[Open Space Technology]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.ietf.org/wg/bof-procedures.html Instructions for Requesting a BOF (Birds of a Feather) Session] at [[IETF]].
[[Category:Meetings]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to birds]]
{{compu-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox recurring event | |name=Bristol Festival of Ideas |logo= |image= arnolfini from across the harbour arp.jpg |caption= The [[Arnolfini]], Bristol, one of the main venues for Festival events |location= [[Bristol]], England –
[[Arnolfini]], [[Watershed Media Centre]], [[St George's Church, Brandon Hill|St. George's]], [[We The Curious]], [[City Hall, Bristol|City Hall]], [[Tobacco Factory]], [[Victoria Rooms (Bristol)|Victoria Rooms]], [[Wills Memorial Building]], etc. |years_active= 2005–present |dates= Throughout year: main Festival programme each May |genre= Arts, science, culture, literature, politics, etc. |website= [http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/ Bristol Festival of Ideas]}} The '''Bristol Festival of Ideas''' is a project established in [[Bristol]], England, which aims "to stimulate people’s minds and passions with an inspiring programme of discussion and debate".[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?page_id=2 Bristol Festival of Ideas] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717045618/http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?page_id=2 |date=17 July 2011 }} website It was first set up in 2005, as part of the city's ultimately unsuccessful bid to become the [[European Capital of Culture]] for 2008, and continues to maintain a programme of debates and other events, including an annual festival each May. The Festival also awards an annual book prize, worth £7,500, to a book which "presents new, important and challenging ideas, which is rigorously argued, and which is engaging and accessible".[http://www.thebookseller.com/news/78585-bristol-festival-of-ideas-reveals-book-prize-shortlist.html.rss Katie Allen, ''Bristol Festival of Ideas reveals Book Prize shortlist'', The Bookseller.com, 26 February 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915054032/http://www.thebookseller.com/news/78585-bristol-festival-of-ideas-reveals-book-prize-shortlist.html.rss |date=15 September 2012 }}[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?page_id=40 Bristol Festival of Ideas: Book Prize] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007174714/http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?page_id=40 |date=7 October 2011 }} It is one of the largest book prizes in the UK.[http://at-bristol.co.uk/640.html At-Bristol: Bristol Festival of Ideas: Book Prize Awards Ceremony, 19 May 2010] The Festival takes place in a range of venues across the city, including the [[Arnolfini]], the [[Watershed Media Centre]], [[St George's Church, Brandon Hill|St. George's]], [[We The Curious]], [[City Hall, Bristol|City Hall]], the [[Tobacco Factory]], and the [[Victoria Rooms (Bristol)|Victoria Rooms]]. It is organised by Bristol Creative Projects (BCP – formerly the Bristol Cultural Development Partnership), [[Arts Council England]], [[Bristol City Council]], and GWE BusinessWest,[http://www.gwebusinesswest.co.uk/about_us.aspx GWE BusinessWest home page] a private sector organisation promoting [[economic development]] in the area, and also works closely with universities in the area and other agencies.[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?page_id=84 Festival of Ideas: Sponsors and Supporters] The Director of the Festival is Andrew Kelly, who was appointed Director of the Bristol Cultural Development Partnership in 1993.[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/pace/graduation/honorary-degrees/hondeg08/kelly.html Bristol University: presentation of honorary degree to Andrew Kelly, 7 November 2008][http://www.cilip.org.uk/groups/plg/pla2007/AndrewKelly.html PLA Conference 2007: biography of Andrew Kelly] ==Events and contributors== ===2005=== The first festival, held 16–21 May 2005, included speakers [[Paul Ormerod]], [[A. C. Grayling]], [[Julia Neuberger]], [[Joanna Bourke]], [[John N. Gray]], [[Colin Tudge]], [[Marek Kohn]], [[Jack Cohen (scientist)|Jack Cohen]], [[Ian Stewart (mathematician)|Ian Stewart]], [[John Carey (critic)|John Carey]], [[John Mortimer]], [[Francis Spufford]], [[Deyan Sudjic]], [[Nick Hornby]], [[Julian Baggini]], [[Claudia Hammond]], [[Dick King-Smith]], [[Roger McGough]], [[Brian Patten]], [[David Crystal]], [[Ben Crystal]], and [[Pat Kane]][http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_05.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas 2005] Kane – formerly a musician in the band [[Hue and Cry (band)|Hue and Cry]] – was appointed as the UK's first "thinker in residence", with a remit to be "a 'constructive heckler' – identifying broad themes that emerge from the discussions, making connections between realms of knowledge ... being a 'contrarian catalyst'".[http://theplayethic.typepad.com/play_journal/2005/04/the_uks_first_t.html Pat Kane, The Play Ethic: ''The UK's first 'Thinker in Residence' is...'', 19 April 2005] ===2006=== The festival, from 9–25 May, was themed around the bicentenary of [[Isambard Kingdom Brunel]]. It looked at "Brunellian themes of creativity and progress and apply[ing] these to issues of contemporary concern and opportunity." Speakers included [[Richard Dowden]], [[Ekow Eshun]], A. C. Grayling, [[Christopher Hitchens]], [[Andrew Roberts (historian)|Andrew Roberts]], [[Lola Young]], [[Jeremy Isaacs]], [[Geoff Dyer]], [[Jonathan Kaplan]], [[Andrea Levy]], [[Tariq Ramadan]], [[Tariq Modood]], [[Julia Hobsbawm]], [[Bryan Appleyard]], [[Joan Bakewell]], [[Tim Harford]], [[Lewis Wolpert]], [[Geoff Mulgan]], [[Philip Ball]], [[Carmen Callil]], [[Lesley Chamberlain]], [[Geoff Mulgan]], [[Chris Smith, Baron Smith of Finsbury|Chris Smith]], [[Eric Sykes]], [[Roy Hattersley]], [[James Lovelock]], [[Charles Handy]], [[Pankaj Mishra]], [[Paul Rusesabagina]], [[Sebastian Junger]], and [[Margaret Atwood]][http://www.bbc.co.uk/bristol/content/articles/2006/04/26/brunel200_festival_ideas_feature.shtml?noCache=9172721 BBC Bristol, ''Festival of Ideas focuses thoughts on Brunel''][http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_06.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas 2006] ===2007=== The 2007 festival, held 9–30 May, sought to explore "questions on the arts, Englishness, happiness and affluence, Africa, big business, spirituality, crime and justice, science and peace." Speakers included [[Wole Soyinka]], [[Steve Fuller (sociologist)|Steve Fuller]], [[Clive Stafford Smith]], [[Steve Bell (cartoonist)|Steve Bell]], [[John Tusa]], [[Billy Bragg]], [[Graham Swift]], [[Oliver James (psychologist)|Oliver James]], [[William Dalrymple (historian)|William Dalrymple]], [[Paddy Ashdown]], [[Nick Cohen]], [[Jasper Fforde]], [[Ziauddin Sardar]], [[David Edgerton (historian)|David Edgerton]], and [[Kiran Desai]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_07.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas 2007] The Festival also ran a short autumn season of lectures, with [[Steven Pinker]], A. C. Grayling, and [[Martin Bell]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_autumn_07.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Autumn 2007] The Festival cancelled an appearance by Nobel Prize-winning scientist [[James D. Watson|James Watson]] after controversy about his statements on [[Race (classification of humans)|race]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/bristol/7052279.stm BBC, ''Festival bars race row scientist'', 19 October 2007] ===2008=== The 2008 spring festival, 3–29 May, aimed to address "many issues including schisms in the Christian Church, the impact of globalisation, science today... fair trade and transition to a greener society, changing America, the media and truth, and what the world would be like without human beings." Speakers included [[John Cornwell (writer)|John Cornwell]], Julian Baggini, [[Alan Sokal]], [[Harriet Lamb]], [[Astrid Proll]], [[Andrew Anthony]], [[Sheila Rowbotham]], [[Dominic Sandbrook]], [[Peter Tatchell]], [[Raymond Tallis]], [[Charles Leadbeater]], [[George Ferguson (architect)|George Ferguson]], [[Jon Ronson]], [[Jean Moorcroft Wilson]], [[Adrian Tinniswood]], [[Andrew Mawson, Baron Mawson|Andrew Mawson]], [[Ben Macintyre]], [[Gerry Anderson]], [[Susan Greenfield]], [[Nick Davies]], [[Simon Singh]], [[Edzard Ernst]], [[Patrick Cockburn]], [[Philippe Sands]], [[Matt Frei]], [[Naomi Klein]], [[Alan Weisman]], [[Kate Mosse]], [[Gary Marcus]], and [[John R. Bolton|John Bolton]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_spring_08.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas Spring 2008] A series of special events were held in autumn 2008, featuring [[Alaa Al Aswany]], [[Tariq Ali]], Deyan Sudjic, [[Richard J. Evans|Richard Evans]], [[Kate Adie]], [[Niall Ferguson]], [[Chris Patten]], [[Colin Blakemore]], [[Jonathan Miller]], [[Richard Gregory]], [[Robert Winston]], [[A. S. Byatt]], [[Semir Zeki]], [[Richard Wentworth (artist)|Richard Wentworth]] and [[Paul Nurse]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_autumn_08.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Autumn 2008] Other speakers during the year included [[John Prescott]], [[Muhammad Yunus]], and [[Tony Benn]]. ===2009=== The 2009 festival focused on three themes – Thirty years of [[Thatcherism]]; [[Charles Darwin|Darwin]] and [[Darwinism]]; and Arts and Science, fifty years after scientist [[C. P. Snow]]'s influential lecture, ''[[The Two Cultures]]''.[http://beta.thisisbristol.co.uk/bristolrugby/news/Festival-ideas-mind/article-1136965-detail/article.html Bristol Evening Post, ''Bristol Festival of ideas is all in the mind'', 4 July 2009] Events during the main Festival featured speakers [[Aravind Adiga]], Tariq Modood, [[Peter Singer]], [[James Lovelock]], A. C. Grayling, [[Christopher Caldwell (journalist)|Christopher Caldwell]], John Gray, [[Richard Holmes (biographer)|Richard Holmes]], Paddy Ashdown, Nick Cohen, [[Wayne Hemingway]], [[Susan Blackmore]], [[Christopher Brookmyre]], [[James Harkin]], Tariq Ramadan, [[David Aaronovitch]], [[Bruce Hood (psychologist)|Bruce Hood]], Geoff Dyer, [[Tristram Hunt]], [[Marcus du Sautoy]], [[Ben Goldacre]], [[Ruth Padel]], [[Richard Fortey]], and [[Gillian Beer]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_may_festival_09.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, May 2009] A programme of events was also held throughout the rest of year. Speakers included [[Clay Shirky]], [[Michael Shermer]], [[Ken Robinson (British author)|Ken Robinson]], [[Leonard Susskind]], [[Steve Jones (biologist)|Steve Jones]], [[Misha Glenny]], [[Daniel Dennett]], [[John Armstrong (British writer/philosopher)|John Armstrong]], [[Chris Anderson (writer)|Chris Anderson]], [[Edward de Bono]], [[Karen Armstrong]], [[Amartya Sen]], Margaret Atwood, [[Richard Dawkins]], [[Sarah Dunant]], [[John Kampfner]], [[Hugh Fearnley-Whittingstall]], [[Simon Schama]], [[Tristram Stuart]], [[Rose George]], [[Zac Goldsmith]], [[Gillian Tett]], [[Neal Lawson]], [[Michael Mansfield]], [[Vic Reeves]], [[Shappi Khorsandi]], [[Alan Davies]], [[Bruce Hood (psychologist)|Bruce Hood]], [[John Micklethwait]], [[Madeleine Bunting]], [[David Attenborough]], [[David Puttnam]], [[William Waldegrave, Baron Waldegrave of North Hill|William Waldegrave]], [[Raj Patel]], [[Vince Cable]], [[Virginia Ironside]], and [[Suzanne Moore]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_spring_09.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Spring 2009][http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_summer_09.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Summer 2009][http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_autumn_09.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Autumn 2009][http://www.bristolnuj.org.uk/2010/11/13/suzanne-moore-to-give-2010-benn-lecture/ Bristol NUJ: ''Suzanne Moore to give 2010 Benn Lecture'', 13 November 2010] In January 2009, the Festival commissioned an artwork to depict people and products that made Bristol famous, as an updated version of a 1930 painting by Ernest Board (1877–1934),[http://bristolfamous.wordpress.com/ernest-board/ Bristol Famous: Ernest Board] ''Some Who Have Made Bristol Famous'', displayed in the [[Bristol City Museum and Art Gallery]].[http://bristolfamous.wordpress.com/boards-1930-painting/ Bristol Famous: ''Board’s 1930 painting''] The commission was won by Simon Gurr,[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?p=335 Bristol Festival of Ideas: ''Winning the commission'', 14 July 2009] and a final list of subjects to appear in the updated version was agreed in 2010.[http://bristolfamous.wordpress.com/about/ Bristol Famous: About] They include [[Wallace and Gromit]]; a special Festival event was held in December 2009, chaired by [[Christopher Frayling]], to mark the 20th anniversary of the creation of the characters by [[Aardman Animations]], based in Bristol.[http://beta.thisisbristol.co.uk/bristolrugby/news/Bristol-Festival-Ideas-mark-Aarman-anniversary/article-1397684-detail/article.html Bristol Evening Post, ''Bristol Festival of Ideas to mark Aardman anniversary'', 7 October 2009] ===2010=== In 2010, special themes included paranoia, inequality, and [[animal rights]], together with "The Bristol Phenomenon", looking at creativity in Bristol through time.[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?p=461 Bristol Festival of Ideas: ''May Festival 2010 launched!'', 18 March 2010] Speakers included [[Barbara Ehrenreich]], [[Stewart Brand]], [[Brian Eno]], [[Albie Sachs]], [[Rebecca Goldstein]], [[Steven Pinker]], [[Germaine Greer]], [[Paul Davies]], [[Phillip Blond]], Peter Singer, Christopher Frayling, [[John Boorman]], [[Will Hutton]], [[Richard G. Wilkinson|Richard Wilkinson]], [[Paul Collier]], [[Norman Stone]], [[Wendy Grossman]], [[Simon Hoggart]], [[Peter Hitchens]], [[Ben Shephard]], [[Ben Goldacre]], [[Francis Wheen]], [[Richard Holloway]], Andrea Levy, [[Mike Hodges]], [[Melvyn Bragg]], [[Dorothy Rowe]], [[David Eagleman]], [[Anthony Julius]], [[John O'Farrell (author)|John O'Farrell]], [[Antonia Fraser]], [[Brooke Magnanti]], [[Gary Younge]], Christopher Hitchens, [[Annie Leonard]], [[Barbara Ehrenreich]], [[Bernhard Schlink]], and [[Will Self]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_spring_10.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, Spring 2010][http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/wp-content/themes/ad-clerum-10/downloadables/foi_brochure_may_festival_10.pdf Bristol Festival of Ideas, May 2010] ===2011=== Programmed speakers in the first part of the year included [[Jimmy Wales]] and [[Evgeny Morozov]].[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/ Bristol Festival of Ideas: home page] The main Festival of Ideas took place 13–22 May 2011.[http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?p=561 Bristol Festival of Ideas: Winter/Spring 2011 events launched] ==Winners of the Bristol Festival of Ideas Book Prize== *2009: ''Flat Earth News'', by [[Nick Davies]][http://www.journalism.co.uk/news-events-awards/nick-davies-awarded--10-000-prize-for-flat-earth-news-/s14/a534333/ Journalism.co.uk, ''Nick Davies awarded £10,000 prize for Flat Earth News''] *2010: ''[[The Spirit Level: Why More Equal Societies Almost Always Do Better|The Spirit Level]]'', by [[Richard G. Wilkinson|Richard Wilkinson]] and [[Kate Pickett]][http://www.york.ac.uk/healthsciences/news-and-events/news/year-2010/bristol-festival/ University of York: Bristol Festival of Ideas Book Prize, 21 May 2010] *2011: ''The Return of the Public'', [[Dan Hind]]http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/?p=1437 ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.ideasfestival.co.uk/}} {{Culture in Bristol}} [[Category:Festivals in Bristol]] [[Category:Philosophy events]]

revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/160.7.21.129|160.7.21.129]] to version by Theinstantmatrix. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3492731) (Bot)
revision.text:
[[File:Eugene de Blaas The Friendly Gossips.jpg|thumb|right|It is speculated that the phrase may come from women chatting while sewing.]] '''''"Chew the fat"''''' or '''''"chew the rag"'''''<ref>Stuart-Hamilton, Ian (Jessica Kingsley Publishers , 2007). [https://books.google.com/books?id=YGSoyM6ChbkC&lpg=PA53&dq=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "chew the fat."] ''An Asperger dictionary of everyday expressions.'' Retrieved 2010-08-09</ref> are English expressions for [[gossip]]ing or making friendly [[small talk]], or a long and informal conversation with someone.<ref>{{cite book|title=Chew the fat definition|url=http://www.theidioms.com/chew-the-fat}}''The Idioms - Online idioms dictionary.''</ref>
==Origin== ===Chew the fat=== Although some sources attribute the phrase "''chew the fat''" to sailors, who during a period of resting and conversing, or while working together,<ref name=food>Palmatier, Robert Allen (2010-08-11). [https://books.google.com/books?id=OqIe3YFwsFkC&lpg=PA62&dq=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&pg=PA62#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "chew the fat."] ''Food: a dictionary of literal and nonliteral terms.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> would chew on salt-hardened fat,<ref>[[Terry Breverton|Breverton, Terry]] (2004, Pelican Publishing Company) [https://books.google.com/books?id=FoNRnUCMrloC&lpg=PA37&ots=P-5H3K8S-B&dq=pirate%20dictionary%20chew%20the%20fat&pg=PA37#v=onepage&q&f=false "Chew the fat."] ''The pirate dictionary.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> there are no reliable historical recordings of this practice. There is even a suggestion the phrase derives from a practice by North American Indians or [[Inuit]] of chewing animal hides during their spare time, and even of British farmers chewing on smoked pork,<ref>Quinion, Michael (2004, Smithsonian Books in association with Penguin Books) [https://books.google.com/books?id=tJtiAAAAMAAJ&q=Random+House+Historical+Dictionary+of+American+Slang+chew+the+rag&dq=Random+House+Historical+Dictionary+of+American+Slang+chew+the+rag&hl=en&ei=fNtiTNGbNoKKlwfe49WbCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ "p. 75."] ''Ballyhoo, buckaroo, and spuds: ingenious tales of words and their origins.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> but again, there remains to be no evidence supporting these claims, and this would require accepting a great deal of uncertainty in connecting the phrase from nautical origins to its modern metaphorical use.<ref name=food/>
There are also claims the phrase is synonymous with the action of chewing on fat, or simply an allusion to the movement of the mouth during chewing.<ref name=barb>Kipfer, Barbara Ann (2008, Sourcebooks). [https://books.google.com/books?id=w2rowi1fm9gC&lpg=PA56&dq=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&pg=PA56#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "Chew the fat."] ''Phraseology.'' Retrieved 2010-08-09</ref> Noting that fried fat is appealing in taste, it was regarded as a treat that someone could chew on for as long as possible to gain the most out of it.<ref>De Mente, Boye Lafeyette (2007, Tuttle Publishing). [https://books.google.com/books?id=cp0r3aa8EM8C&lpg=PA72&dq=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&pg=PA72#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "Chew the fat."] ''Cheater's Guide to Speaking English Like a Native .'' Retrieved 2010-08-10</ref>
The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''{{'s}} earliest citation for "''Chew the fat''" is from 1885 in a book by J Brunlees Patterson called ''Life in the Ranks of the British Army in India''. He implied it was a kind of general grumbling and bending of the ears of junior officers to stave off boredom, a typical part of army life.<ref name=ww/> Patterson also uses "chew the rag" in the same sentence he used "chew the fat", but it is not the oldest occurrence of that phrase.<ref name=ww/> Prior to the adoption of metallic cartridges, most ammunition was composed of powder and a ball wrapped in paper or cloth soaked in animal fat, which was bitten open during musket drill. Soldiers were known to chew on these ends to pass the time and reduce nerves, and in some cases to stave off cravings for chewing tobacco. Though long-since replaced by 1885, the idea of biting or chewing on fat-soaked rag ends may well have entered military parlance in this fashion prior to Patterson's recording.{{Citation needed|date=September 2012}}
===Chew the rag=== Appearing first in print from 1875 in "Random House Historical Dictionary of American Slang", the excerpt reads: {{Quote|"''Gents, I could '''chew the rag''' hours on end, just spilling out the words and never know no more than a billy-goat what I’d been saying.''"<ref name=ww/>}} There is speculation this phrase relates to cloth, when ladies would work in "[[sewing circles]]",<ref name=her>Ammer, Christine (1997, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt). [https://books.google.com/books?id=9re1vfFh04sC&pg=PA114&dq=%22chew+the+fat%22&hl=en&ei=GzdgTLPIFcGB8gban9HEDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "chew the fat."] ''The American Heritage dictionary of idioms.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> or that women may have gossiped while quilting.<ref name=food/>
===Shared use=== The first appeared synonymously as early as 1885,<ref name=barb/> in J. Brunlees Patterson's "Life in the ranks of the British army in India and on board a troopship", which listed the terms in succession: {{Quote|''"..whistling, singing, arguing the point, '''chewing the rag''', or '''fat''', or other voluble and noisy inflictions, such as the screeching and gabbling of parrots and yelping of canines..''"<ref>Patterson, J. Brunless (1885). [https://books.google.com/books?id=1YADAAAAQAAJ&q=%22Life+in+the+Ranks+of+the+British+Army%22&dq=%22Life+in+the+Ranks+of+the+British+Army%22&hl=en&ei=HfJiTLeSFsL7lweFo7GvCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAg "''...spirits and others who indulge in the various diversions of whistling, singing..''"] ''Life in the ranks of the British army in India and on board a troopship.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref>}} It was used as a way to describe complaining or grumbling,<ref name=barb/> typically by the military.
==Modern usage== It was not until 1907 the phrase "''chew the fat''" was used to express partaking in idle conversation,<ref name=barb/> for a friendly talk, or a gossip session.<ref name=her/> It has also been used to a way to define telling tall tales.<ref name=myth/>
In [[ham radio]], extended conversation, as opposed to just exchanging basic information (name, location, equipment), is called "ragchewing".<ref>[http://amateur-radio-wiki.net/index.php?title=Rag_chewers_club Rag Chewers Club]</ref>
''[[Chewin' the Fat]]'' was the title of a Scottish [[comedy]] [[sketch show]], starring [[Ford Kiernan]], [[Greg Hemphill]] and [[Karen Dunbar]]. ''[[Chewin' the Fat]]'' first started as a [[radio]] series on [[BBC Radio Scotland]].
''Chew-The-Fat.com'' is a UK-based website (now moved to chew-the-fat.org.uk) hosting a web [[Internet forum|forum]], described as "The chat forum your mother warned you about", devoted to chat, gossip, and humorous banter and cartoons.<ref>[http://www.chew-the-fat.org.uk/ Chew-The-Fat.com]</ref>
==Email hoax== [[File:Bacon (1).jpg|right|150px]] In 1999, a widespread hoax called "Life in the 1500s", false information was circulated through email regarding ''"chew the fat"''.<ref name=snopes>Mikkelson, Barbara (2007-07-12). [http://www.snopes.com/language/phrases/1500.asp "Life in the 1500s."] ''Snopes.com'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> Among offering explanations for many phrases, the email stated: {{Quote|"''When company came over, they would bring out some bacon and hang it to show it off. It was a sign of wealth and that a man 'could really bring home the bacon.' They would cut off a little to share with guests and would all sit around and 'chew the fat.' ''"<ref>[http://www.virtualteacher.com.au/life.html "Life in the 1500s."] ''Virtual Teachers.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref>}} Notably, [[Karl Pilkington]] propagated this story during episode eight of the second series of ''[[The Ricky Gervais Show]]'' on XFM London. The false email spurred a reexamination of popularly sourced etymologies of many folk phrases and idioms.<ref name=myth>Wilton, David (2004, Oxford University Press). [https://books.google.com/books?id=cp0r3aa8EM8C&pg=PA72&dq=%22chew+the+fat%22&hl=en&ei=GzdgTLPIFcGB8gban9HEDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22chew%20the%20fat%22&f=false "Chew the fat."] ''Word myths: debunking linguistic urban legends.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref><ref name=snopes/><ref name=led>Lederer, Richard (2003, MacMillan). [https://books.google.com/books?id=vFKwSJXrXKQC&lpg=PA163&pg=PA163#v=onepage&q&f=false "Spook etymology on the Internet."] ''A man of my words: reflections on the English language.'' Section regarding this article available [http://www.jewishworldreview.com/0203/lederer022003.asp here] Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> Although it has been widely accepted as accurate,<ref name=ww>Quinion, Michael (2007-11-03). [http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-che5.htm "Chew the fat."] ''World Wide Words.'' Retrieved 2010-08-11</ref> this misinformation has since been dispelled.
==References== {{Wiktionary|chew the fat}} {{Wiktionary|chew the rag}} {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chew The Fat}} [[Category:Human communication]] [[Category:English phrases]] [[Category:Internet hoaxes]] [[Category:1999 hoaxes]] [[Category:Metaphors referring to food and drink]]
Music album by James Patrick Gavin- Chewing The Fat
