revision.text:
The '''Sharm El Sheikh Summit of 2005''' took place on 8 February, when four [[Middle East]]ern leaders gathered at [[Sharm El Sheikh]], in the [[Sinai Peninsula]], in an effort to end the four-year [[Second Intifada|Al-Aqsa Intifada]]. The four leaders were [[Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Ariel Sharon]], [[President of the Palestinian Authority]] [[Mahmoud Abbas]], [[Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], and [[King Abdullah II]] of Jordan.
Sharon and Abbas explicitly undertook to cease all violence against each other's peoples, marking a formal end to the Al-Aqsa Intifada and to move on in the [[Road map for peace]] process. Sharon also agreed to release 900 [[Palestinian prisoners in Israel|Palestinian prisoners]] of the 7,500 being held at the time,<ref name=Reinhardtp77>{{cite book|title=The Road Map to Nowhere: Israel/Palestine Since 2003|author=[[Tanya Reinhart]]|publisher=Verso|year=2006|isbn= 9781844670765|page=77}}</ref> and to withdraw from West Bank towns. However, the violence continued into the following years, though suicide bombings decreased significantly. By the spring of 2005, 500 of the prisoners had been released, but after [[Qassam rocket]] attacks on [[Sderot]] on 5 May, Sharon stopped the release of the remaining 400, saying the Palestinian Authority needs to rein in the militants.<ref name=Drakulichp79>{{cite book|title=A Global Agenda: Issues Before the 60th General Assembly of the United Nations|author=Angela Drakulich, United Nations Association of the United States of America|publisher=United Nations Publications|year=2005|isbn= 9781880632710|page=79|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Nn41RSRpoaIC&pg=PA79&dq=palestinian+prisoners+israel+1948#PPA79,M1}}</ref>
==Background to the summit== The [[Second Intifada|Al-Aqsa Intifada]], which began in September 2000, left over 5,000 [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] and [[Israel]]i casualties and took extensive toll on both economies and societies. The cycle of violence persisted throughout this period, except for the short-lived [[Hudna]] in mid-2003.
Neither side was willing to negotiate until there was a halt to violence. [[Yasser Arafat]], the man thought by many to have engineered the intifada and to have kept it alive, died in November 2004. The [[Palestinian presidential election, 2005|Palestinian presidential election]] to elect Arafat's successor was held on 9 January 2005 and confirmed [[Mahmoud Abbas]] as President of the [[Palestinian Authority]]. His initial efforts were to bring order to the anarchy of the Palestinian territories and halt attacks against Israel. [[Ariel Sharon]] changed his attitude towards negotiations and ordered a significant reduction of Israeli military activity in the Palestinian territories and took many measures to help Palestinian civilians.
These trust-building steps, together with renewed security coordination between the two sides and the backing of the [[United States]], [[Jordan]] and [[Egypt]] led to agreement on holding of the summit.
==The summit== The summit began with a series of meetings between Sharon and Mubarak, King Abdullah and Abbas. Later, all leaders except King Abdullah read statements reaffirming their commitment to continued efforts to stabilize the situation and to move on in the [[Road map for peace]] process.
Sharon and Abbas explicitly included an intended cessation of all violent activity against each other's peoples in their closing statements,<ref name=Abbas_Sharm>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4247327.stm |title=The full text of Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas's declaration of a ceasefire with the Israelis at the Sharm al-Sheikh summit |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2005 |accessdate=28 September 2014 |quote=We have agreed with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon to stop all acts of violence against Israelis and Palestinians, wherever they are. ... [w]e have announced today not only represents the implementation of the first articles of the roadmap....}}</ref><ref name=Sharon_Sharm>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4247233.stm |title=The full text of Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's declaration of a ceasefire with the Palestinians at the Sharm al-Sheikh summit |publisher=BBC News |date=8 February 2005 |accessdate=28 September 2014 |quote=Today, in my meeting with Chairman Abbas, we agreed that all Palestinians will stop all acts of violence against all Israelis everywhere and, in parallel, Israel will cease all its military activity against all Palestinians anywhere. ... The disengagement plan can pave the way to implementation of the roadmap, to which we are committed and which we want to implement.}}</ref> marking a formal end to the Al-Aqsa Intifada. Sharon also agreed to release 900 [[Palestinian prisoners in Israel|Palestinian prisoners]] and to withdraw from West Bank towns.
==Media coverage post-summit== A 2007 report entitled "Quiet, We're Disengaging! Israeli Media Coverage of the Tense Ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinian Authority Following the Sharm El Sheikh Understandings" by the Israeli media monitoring NGO [https://web.archive.org/web/20090628024544/http://www.keshev.org.il/siteEn/default.asp Keshev] (trans. "Awareness"):<ref name="keshev">{{cite web|title=Keshev – Keshev Publications <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE -->|url=http://www.keshev.org.il/siteEn/FullNews.asp?NewsID=125&CategoryID=9)|work=|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5ioW9ivp9?url=http://www.keshev.org.il/siteEn/FullNews.asp?NewsID=125&CategoryID=9)|archivedate=2009-08-06|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-08-01|df=}}</ref>
{{quote|the Israeli media played down Israeli violations of the Sharm El Sheikh understandings and highlighted Palestinian violations.
[[Criticism of Israel]], by Palestinian, Israeli and international actors, appeared infrequently and always on the margins of the news. Criticism of Palestinians, by contrast, was covered profusely. In general, policy questions concerning Israeli violations of the ceasefire received secondary attention, as the media coverage mainly focused on the disengagement plan.
These patterns of coverage and editing, which broadly covered each Palestinian attack on Israelis, provided media consumers with a clear and unequivocal situation report: Israel is abiding by its commitments and in the vast majority of cases it is not endangering the ceasefire. The [[Palestinian Authority]], on the other hand, is consistently breaking its commitments and its leader, [[Abu Mazen]] [Abbas], does not want or cannot keep the ceasefire for any length of time. The ceasefire is therefore bound to collapse – and the Palestinians bear exclusive responsibility for this.<ref name="Keshev 1">{{cite web |url=http://www.keshev.org.il/siteEn/FullNews.asp?NewsID=87&CategoryID=9 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721144035/http://www.keshev.org.il/siteEn/FullNews.asp?NewsID=87&CategoryID=9 |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref>}}
The report also notes: {{quote|In this sense, the Israeli media continues to operate according to the prevailing established point of view, according to which the Palestinian Authority is not a "partner". This perspective also forms the basis for the unilateral disengagement from the Gaza Strip.<ref name="keshev 3">{{cite web |url=http://www.keshev.org.il/FileUpload/KESHEV_2nd_Report_ENG.pdf |title=Archived copy: Keshev Report: Quiet, We’re Disengaging! Israeli Media Coverage of the Tense Ceasefire between Israel and the Palestinian Authority following the Sharm e-Sheikh Understandings |accessdate=2009-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721144144/http://www.keshev.org.il/FileUpload/KESHEV_2nd_Report_ENG.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-21 |df= }}</ref>}}
==See also==
===Arab–Israeli peace diplomacy and treaties=== *[[Paris Peace Conference, 1919]] *[[Faisal–Weizmann Agreement]] (1919) *[[1949 Armistice Agreements]] *[[Camp David Accords (1978)]] *[[Egypt–Israel Peace Treaty]] (1979) *[[Madrid Conference of 1991]] *[[Oslo Accords]] (1993) *[[Israel–Jordan peace treaty]] (1994) *[[Camp David 2000 Summit]] *[[Israeli–Palestinian peace process]] *[[Projects working for peace among Israelis and Arabs]] *[[List of Middle East peace proposals]] *[[International law and the Arab–Israeli conflict]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4247327.stm Full text of Abbas declaration] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4247233.stm Full text of Sharon declaration]

revision.text:
In [[United States law|American law]], [[Scots law]] and under the law of some English-speaking [[Commonwealth]] nations, '''subornation of perjury''' is the [[crime]] of persuading a person to commit [[perjury]], the swearing of a false oath to tell the truth in a legal proceeding, whether spoken or written. The term ''subornation of perjury'' further describes the circumstance wherein an [[lawyer|attorney at law]] causes a client to lie under oath or allows another party to lie under oath.<ref name="NAS">{{cite web|url=http://www.nas.gov.uk/guides/legalTerms.asp|title=Scots Legal Terms and Offences Libelled|publisher=National Archives of Scotland|accessdate=19 May 2012|location=Edinburgh|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120530035318/http://www.nas.gov.uk/guides/legalTerms.asp|archivedate=30 May 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>Garner, Bryan A., Ed., ''Black's Law Dictionary'' 7th Ed. West Group, St. Paul Minnesota, 1999, p. 1440.</ref>
In American federal law, Title {{United States Code|18|1622}} provides:
{{quote|Whoever procures another to commit any perjury is guilty of subornation of perjury, and shall be fined under this title or imprisoned not more than five years, or both.}}
In California law, per the State bar Code,<ref>''In re Rivas'' (1989) 49 Cal.3d 794, 263 California Reporter. 654, 781 P.2d 946</ref> the subornation of perjury constitutes an act of "[[moral turpitude]]" on the part of the attorney, and thus is cause for his or her disbarment, or for the suspension of his or her license to practice law.<ref>California Business & Professions Code §6102(a)</ref>
In legal practice, the condition of suborning perjury applies to a lawyer who presents either [[testimony]] or an [[affidavit]], or both, either to a [[judge]] or to a [[jury]], which the attorney knows to be [[Materiality (law)|materially]] false, and not factual. In [[civil law (common law)|civil law]] and in [[criminal law]], the attorney's knowledge that the testimony is materially false must rise above mere [[suspicion (emotion)|suspicion]] to what an attorney would reasonably have believed in the circumstances of the matter discussed in the testimony. Hence, the attorney cannot be [[willful blindness|wilfully blind]] to the fact that his or her witness is giving false, perjurious testimony.
An attorney who encourages a witness to give false testimony is suborning [[perjury]], a crime punished either with formal disciplinary action, [[disbarment]], jail or a combination thereof. A false statement by an attorney in court also is a crime similar to subornation of perjury and is punished accordingly. In the professional conduct of an attorney at law, there is a fine delineation between assisting a witness to recall events and encouraging him or her to give materially false testimony. The practice of ″horse shedding the witness″ (rehearsing testimony) is an example of such perjurious criminal conduct by an attorney, which is depicted in the true-crime novel ''[[Anatomy of a Murder]]'' (1958), by [[John D. Voelker|Robert Traver]] and in the eponymous film (Otto Preminger, 1959), about a rape-and-murder case wherein are explored the [[Legal ethics|ethical]] and legal problems inherent to the subornation of perjury.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=kjwVASsTUm0C&pg=PA445&lpg=PA445&dq=%22horse+shedding%22&source=web&ots=DnNsSClpMd&sig=rGf9tg3HTgWmCNOBBC6u_4IsBAA#PPA445,M1 “Horse shedding” term, ''Quote it Completely!'' (1969) pp. 445–446.]</ref><ref name="hs_kentlaw">{{cite web|url=http://www.kentlaw.edu/faculty/rwarner/classes/carter/2008_lectures/Horseshedding,%20Lecturing%20and%20Legal%20Ethics.pdf|title=Horse-shedding, Lecturing and Legal Ethics|author=Edward Carter|year=2008|publisher=Illinois Institute of Technology, Chicago-Kent College of Law|accessdate=2011-06-04}}</ref><ref>''See'' Garner, B.A. Ed., ''Black's Law Dictionary'' 7th Ed., 1999, pp. 742, 1342, and 1598.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==See also== *[[Jury tampering]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Subornation Of Perjury}} [[Category:Crimes]] [[Category:Perjury]] [[Category:Scots law legal terminology]] [[Category:Scottish criminal law]] [[Category:United States criminal law]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
[[Image:George McClellan at Taylor Opera House.jpg|right|thumb|275px|Democratic State Convention of 1877 at the Opera House]] '''Taylor Opera House''' was an [[opera]] house in [[Trenton, New Jersey]]. It was the city's first theater, and was founded by [[John Taylor (Taylor Ham)|John Taylor]], creator of Pork Roll and one of Trenton's leading citizens. The building first opened March 18, 1867 at 18 S. Broad Street. A historical marker was placed on the site after its demolition.<ref>[http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=3991 Historical Marker Database: Taylor Opera House]</ref>
The theater presented the major speakers and performers of the day, including [[Mark Twain]], [[Ethel Barrymore]], and [[George M. Cohan]], and played host to political conventions, Bible conferences, musical revues and local meetings and events. It hosted the inaugurations of Governor [[George B. McClellan]] in 1877, and [[Woodrow Wilson]] in 1910,<ref>[http://www.trentonhistory.org/Documents/Manuscript1900.htm Trenton Historical Society]</ref> [[James Fairman Fielder|James F. Fielder]] in 1914<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B05EEDF113FE633A2575AC1A9679C946596D6CF "FIELDER IN TO-MORROW.; Jersey's New Governor to Take Oath of Office at Noon."], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 19, 1914. Accessed December 29, 2007. "At midnight to-morrow New Jersey will have a new Governor, James F. Fielder of Jersey City, but he will not take the oath of office until Tuesday at noon.... The Legislature will assemble at the State House shortly before 12 o'clock on Tuesday and then proceed to the Taylor Opera House."</ref> and [[Walter Evans Edge]] in 1917.<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9F01E0D6163AE433A25756C1A9679C946696D6CF "EDGE IN OFFICE TOMORROW.; Inaugural in Opera House;-Parade and Social Affairs."], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 15, 1917. Accessed December 29, 2007. "Everything is ready for the inauguration here Tuesday of Walter E. Edge of Atlantic City, Republican, as Governor of New Jersey. The induction ceremonies will be held in the Taylor Opera House."</ref>
In 1921, it was converted into a movie and vaudeville palace known as '''Keith's Capitol Theatre'''; after later sales it was renamed the '''RKO International'''.
The theater was razed by its next door neighbor (the [[Trenton Saving Fund Society]]) to create a parking lot in 1969.<ref>Modica, Glenn R. "[http://www.trentondowntowner.com/default.php?article=1006 Trenton Saving Fund Society] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116074359/http://trentondowntowner.com/default.php?article=1006 |date=2006-11-16 }}", ''Trenton Downtowner''. January 2006</ref>

{{Primary sources|date=June 2018}} {{Notability|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox play | name = The Trainer | writer = David Wilson and Anne Aylor (with [[Keith Burstein]]) | date of premiere = 2009 | country of Origin = {{UK}} | genre = Political
}} '''''The Trainer''''' is a play by David Wilson and Anne Aylor (with writing contributions from composer [[Keith Burstein]]).
==Description==
''The Trainer'' is a multi-media play set in a posh gym in the basement of a gentlemen’s club, punctuated with excerpts from the (real life) opera ''[[Manifest Destiny (opera)|Manifest Destiny]]'', news footage from [[Gaza City|Gaza]] and inane breakfast TV programmes. It delivers a darkly comical comment on the justice system, while at the same time highlighting the struggles taking place both in Gaza and in the UK and other Western countries to defend humanity from barbarism.
==Synopsis==
The play explores the love story between a British Jew, Josh, and his Palestinian fiancée Taghreed (who works as a fitness trainer at the gym in a London gentlemen's club). Their story is interwoven with a predominantly fact-based account of the real-life bankruptcy of British composer [[Keith Burstein]] (as the result of a libel trial relating to issues of alleged promotion of terrorism) as told by the attendees of the gym in which Taghreed works (all of whom happen to be Judges of the Court of Appeal).
==Background==
After [[Keith Burstein]] and [[Dic Edwards]]’ opera ''[[Manifest Destiny (opera)|Manifest Destiny]]'' was performed at the [[2005 Edinburgh Festival Fringe]] the ''[[Evening Standard|London Evening Standard]]'' newspaper published a review which claimed that the opera glorified terrorism. Burstein subsequently took the newspaper to court on the grounds that this claim put him at risk under the terms of the Terrorism Acts of 2005 and 2006. The High Court found in his favour and granted him the right to take the case to a trial by jury. However, this decision was reversed in the Court of Appeal, which ordered Burstein to pay the legal costs of the ''[[Evening Standard|London Evening Standard]]'' (some £70,000). In consequence, Burstein was bankrupted and the Official Receiver seized possession of all of his works (including ''[[Manifest Destiny (opera)|Manifest Destiny]]'').
The court case and its aftermath inspired David Wilson and Anne Aylor (in collaboration with Burstein) to write ''The Trainer''. The play covers a fictionalised version of the events of the trial, in parallel with a separate plot strand similar to one used in ''[[Manifest Destiny (opera)|Manifest Destiny]]'' (that of an educated Palestinian woman with a Jewish lover, driven towards acts of violence in response to the state violence demonstrated in the Middle Eastern conflicts of the late 20th and early 21st centuries).
==Performance history==
''The Trainer'' premiered at Oxford House, London, in March 2009. Actors involved included [[Corin Redgrave]], [[Tim Pigott-Smith]] and Lebanese-American actress Jana Zeineddine.
Following rewrites, ''The Trainer'' was revived for the fundraising evening ''Two Plays For Gaza'' on May 21, 2009 at the [[Hackney Empire]] theatre in London, UK (which also featured a performance of [[Caryl Churchill]]'s play ''[[Seven Jewish Children]]'', talks by [[Tony Benn]] and Ben Griffin, and music from [[Reem Kelani]] and hip-hop poet [[Lowkey]].) For this production, actors [[Janie Dee]] and [[Roger Lloyd-Pack]] joined the cast.
Both productions were directed by Tom Platten.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.barebonesproductions.co.uk/ Barebones Productions (UK)] - production company handling ''The Trainer'' *[http://www.anneaylor.co.uk Anne Aylor's homepage] *[http://www.keithburstein.co.uk Keith Burstein's homepage]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Trainer}} [[Category:2009 plays]] [[Category:British plays]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in fiction]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in London]] [[Category:Plays about the Israeli–Palestinian conflict]]

{{Infobox convention | name = '''Tiger Conference''' | image = [[File:Logo of the Tiger Conference.png|300px|]] | status = | genre = Business | frequency = Annual | location = [[Kiev]] | country = [[Ukraine]] | first = 2012 | last = | founders = [[Kyiv Post]] | CEO = | organizer = | attendance = | website = https://tiger.kyivpost.com/ }} '''Tiger Conference''' is an annual [[conference]], founded in 2012<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://labs.kyivpost.com/tiger2017/6th_TIGER_Conference.pdf|title=Tiger Conference Chronology|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|language=|accessdate=}}</ref> by the [[Kyiv Post]]. The conference brings together more than 400 [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] and world leaders, top managers, top executives of leading companies, media, parliamentarians, diplomats and opinion leaders to exchange ideas about the future of [[Ukraine]] in a changing world.
Since 2016, Kyiv Post has launched a "Top 30 Under 30" [[List of awards|award ceremony]], selected by jury on the basis of nominations from readers and business community. This ceremony completes the conference.
As of 2018, the Tiger Conference has become an independent discussion platform for discussing the strongest challenges of Ukraine.
== Format == The event holds 4 panel discussions, speeches delivered by key speakers, 2 sectional meetings and the award ceremony of the 30 most successful young Ukrainians "TOP30UNDER30".
== Top 30 Under 30 == [[File:Logo 30UNDER30 Ukraine.png|thumb|Official logo of the nomination]] The Top 30 Under 30 [[nomination]] is a popular practice among international editions, research organizations such as [[Forbes]]. In Ukraine, the award was launched in 2016 by [[Kyiv Post|KyivPost]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://tiger.kyivpost.com/page1414128.html|title=6th Tiger Conference|website=tiger.kyivpost.com|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref> in partnership with the [[Victor Pinchuk Foundation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pinchukfund.org/ua/news/17090/|title=Фонд Віктора Пінчука - Новини|website=pinchukfund.org|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref>
Every year special jury creates a list of the top 30 most successful young Ukrainians, who inspires and proves that Ukraine has a bright future.
The winners of the nomination must be a [[Citizenship|citizen]] of Ukraine who has not yet reached the age of 30 years and have outstanding achievements in the fields of [[education]], [[health care]], [[business]], [[science]], [[medicine]], social activities, [[art]] and other fields.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.prostir.ua/?grants=nominatsiya-top-30-under-30-vid-kyiv-post-tryvaje-pryjom-zayavok|title=Номінація TOP 30 UNDER 30 від Kyiv Post – триває прийом заявок {{!}} Громадський простір|website=www.prostir.ua|language=uk|accessdate=2018-10-03}}</ref> The award is realized in a crystal engraving [[Figurine|statuette]].
== Speakers and themes == During the 7 years og the Tiger Conference, among the speakers there were: [[Mikheil Saakashvili]], [[Petro Poroshenko]], [[Dmytro Shymkiv]], [[Ariel Cohen]], [[Mark Galeotti]], [[Oksana Syroyid]], [[Michael Bolchuk]], [[Mark Hertling|Mark Hartling]] and others.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nucc.no/events/5th-tiger-conference/|title=NUCC {{!}} 5th TIGER revision.text:
'''Venus Over Manhattan''' was founded in 2012 by [[Adam Lindemann]]. The gallery is now known as [http://venusovermanhattan.com/ VENUS], with spaces operating in both Manhattan and Los Angeles. The New York space is dedicated to curated exhibitions both historic and contemporary, which cast a unique and often iconoclastic view on the work of established artists or artists whose works have been somewhat overlooked. Past exhibitions have included those of [[Alexander Calder]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Brienne Walsh |url=http://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/alexander-calder-venus-over-manhattan-salon-94 |title=Two Exhibitions Give Alexander Calder Works a Fresh Look |publisher=Architectural Digest |date=2013-10-31 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=By Pei-Ru Keh |url=http://www.wallpaper.com/art/new-yorks-venus-over-manhattan-gallery-casts-rare-works-by-alexander-calder-in-a-whole-new-light |title=New York's Venus Over Manhattan gallery casts rare works by Alexander Calder in a whole new light | Wallpaper* |publisher=Wallpaper.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Jack Goldstein]],<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/21/arts/design/where-is-jack-goldstein.html</ref> [[William Copley (artist)|William Copley]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Priscilla Frank Arts Writer, The Huffington Post |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/14/william-copley-and-big-fat-black-cock-inc-join-forces-for-a-very-nsfw-exhibition-gang-bust-_n_3053600.html |title=William Copley And BFBC Inc. Join Forces For Sugary Sweet NSFW Exhibition, 'Gang Bust' (PHOTOS) |publisher=Huffington Post |date=2013-04-14 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Raymond Pettibon]],<ref>http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/07/on-view-raymond-pettibons-surf-paintings-ride-into-manhattan/</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wmagazine.com/culture/eye-candy/2014/04/raymond-pettibon-dan-attoe/photos/slide/1 |title=New Surfing Exhibitions by Raymond Pettibon and Dan Attoe |publisher=W Magazine |date=2014-04-02 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> Walter Dahn,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/art/walter-dahn-4th-time-around-my-back-pages |title=Walter Dahn, "4th Time Around/(My Back Pages)" | Art in New York |publisher=Timeout.com |date=2013-10-04 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Peter Saul]],<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/13/arts/design/review-peter-saul-from-pop-to-punk-a-firebrand-willing-to-offend.html</ref> and [[H. C. Westermann|H.C. Westermann]].<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/06/arts/design/an-hc-westermann-retrospective-melds-humor-and-provocation.html</ref> In New York, VENUS has collaborated with artist foundations, estates, and galleries including The [[Alexander Calder|Calder]] Foundation, [[White Columns]], [[Sprüth Magers (art gallery)|Sprüth Magers]], [[David Zwirner Gallery|David Zwirner]], the estate of William Copley and the estate of Allan Frumkin.
VENUS opened its Los Angeles space in May 2015.<ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/06/arts/design/texas-museum-to-build-ellsworth-kelly-design.html?ref=design&_r=0</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=John Wogan |url=http://www.architecturaldigest.com/story/cant-miss-art-galleries-in-downtown-los-angeles |title=Can’t-Miss Art Galleries in Downtown Los Angeles |publisher=Architectural Digest |date=2016-03-14 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Wyrick |first=Chris |url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/news-features/interviews/go-west-young-goddess-adam-lindemann-opens-venus-over-los-angeles/ |title=Go West, Young Goddess: Adam Lindemann Opens Venus Over Los Angeles - Interviews - Art in America |publisher=Artinamericamagazine.com |date=2015-05-01 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2015/04/15/venus-over-manhattan-goes-to-california/ |title=Venus Over Manhattan Goes to California |publisher=ARTnews |date= |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/1136258/venus-rising-over-la-gallery-makes-moves-to-west-coast |title=Venus Rising Over L.A.: Gallery Makes Moves to West Coast |publisher=Blouin Artinfo |date=2015-04-18 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=May 1, 2016 |url=http://robbreport.com/art-collectibles/best-new-art-galleries-los-angeles |title=The Best New Art Galleries in Los Angeles | Art & Collectibles |publisher=Robbreport.com |date=2016-05-01 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> The Los Angeles gallery hosts a primary program in a 14,500 square foot exhibition space in the downtown arts district. It presents exhibitions by a roster of established and emerging talent including [[Dan Colen]],<ref>{{cite web|author=In the Air |url=http://blogs.artinfo.com/artintheair/2015/05/05/venus-over-los-angeles-opens-with-pared-down-dan-colen/ |title=Venus Over Los Angeles Opens with Pared Down Dan Colen Show | In the Air | BLOUIN ARTINFO Blogs |publisher=Blogs.artinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Katherine Bernhardt]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wmagazine.com/culture/art-and-design/2015/07/katherine-bernhardt-venus-over-los-angeles/photos/ |title=Katherine Bernhardt Comes to Venus Over Los Angeles |publisher=W Magazine |date=2015-07-27 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> Dan McCarthy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-dan-mccarthy-at-venus-over-los-angeles-20151012-story.html |title=Dan McCarthy's 'Facepots': The smiles never end in this L.A. world |publisher=LA Times |date=2015-10-16 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Adel Abdessemed]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Wagley |first=Catherine |url=http://www.laweekly.com/event/adel-abdessemed-from-here-to-eternity-6307598 |title=Adel Abdessemed: From Here to Eternity | Venus Over Los Angeles | Art Galleries | Los Angeles News and Events |publisher=LA Weekly |date=2015-12-19 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> [[Marianne Vitale]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Wagley |first=Catherine |url=http://www.laweekly.com/arts/5-art-shows-you-should-see-in-la-this-week-6508531 |title=5 Art Shows You Should See in L.A. This Week: A Requiem for Sandra Bland and more |publisher=L.A. Weekly |date=2016-01-27 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref> and [[Elaine Cameron-Weir]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-elaine-cameron-weir-venus-over-los-angeles-review-20160322-column.html |title=Lead jackets, copper snakeskins: the sculptural inventions of Elaine Cameron-Weir |publisher=LA Times |date=2016-03-30 |accessdate=2016-09-21}}</ref>
